title: 110_hr4158
content: The "National Urban Search and Rescue Response System Act of 2007" clarifies the authority of the Administrator of FEMA to manage the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System for all hazards. It amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to include the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System. The "National Urban Search and Rescue Response System Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Administrator, Agency, Hazard, Participating agency, Sponsoring agency, and System for the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System. The National Urban Search and Rescue Response System, as defined in the Act, includes terms like System, System member, and Task force. The Administrator is responsible for administering the emergency response system and establishing a national network for standardized search and rescue operations. The Administrator is responsible for designating task forces to participate in the national network of standardized search and rescue resources. Each task force must have a sponsoring agency, and may include participating agencies as determined by the sponsoring agency. The sponsoring agency of a task force must have agreements with participating agencies and may include other individuals. The Administrator maintains management and technical teams. The Administrator may appoint System members into Federal service for participation in various activities without following certain civil service laws. The Administrator can appoint System members into Federal service for specific activities without affecting other authorities under the Act. System members appointed into Federal service are not considered U.S. employees for purposes outside of this section. The Administrator can reimburse employers of System members on task forces for compensation paid during their Federal service appointment. The Administrator can appoint System members into Federal service for specific activities and reimburse employers for compensation paid during their appointment. During a System member's appointment into Federal service, the employer can be reimbursed for compensation paid, with limitations on costs eligible for reimbursement. The System member cannot receive direct pay from the Agency during this period. Personal injury, illness, disability, or death are covered under this provision. "A System member appointed into Federal service under subsection (f)(1) who suffers personal injury, illness, disability, or death as a result of an injury sustained during the appointment is treated as an employee for benefits purposes. The member or their dependent may elect to receive benefits." System members or dependents must elect to receive benefits under subchapter I of chapter 81 of title 5, United States Code, or benefits from a State or local government within one year of the injury, illness, disability, or death. System members or dependents must elect benefits under subchapter I of chapter 81 of title 5, United States Code, or from a State or local government within one year of the injury, illness, disability, or death. The election of benefits is irrevocable unless otherwise provided by law. The Administrator shall reimburse the State or local government for the value of benefits elected. Liabilities of System members appointed into Federal service are outlined. System members appointed into Federal service are deemed employees of the United States under certain sections of the United States Code, relating to tort claims procedure. Service as a System member is considered 'service in the uniformed services' for employment and reemployment rights purposes. System members appointed into Federal service are considered employees of the United States under specific sections of the United States Code. The obligations, procedures for assistance, enforcement, and investigation are outlined in the chapter. Preclusion of giving notice of service by necessity of appointment is deemed preclusion by 'military necessity' for certain purposes. Determination of such necessity is made by the Administrator and is not subject to judicial review. If a System member holds a valid license, certificate, or permit issued by any State or governmental jurisdiction, they are deemed to be performing a professional skill required by the System. The System member is considered to be performing a Federal activity when providing aid during a period of appointment into Federal service. The Administrator establishes an advisory committee to provide expert recommendations for administering the System, composed of members from diverse areas and specific agencies. The Administrator establishes an advisory committee with diverse members recommended by task force leaders. The committee is exempt from termination requirements of the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Administrator enters into annual preparedness cooperative agreements with sponsoring agencies for training, exercises, and equipment acquisition. The Administrator enters into response cooperative agreements with sponsoring agencies for equipment acquisition, medical monitoring, and interoperable communications. Unused funds are deposited in an Agency account for future agreements. The Administrator enters into response cooperative agreements with sponsoring agencies to reimburse costs incurred in responding to disasters. The Administrator may incur necessary obligations to ensure the System's effectiveness. $52,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2009-2011, in addition to funds from the Disaster Relief Fund. Administrative expenses may be covered by the Administrator. The Administrator can use up to 6 percent of appropriated funds for administrative expenses. Amendments are made to the applicability of title 5, United States Code for System members of the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System. Amendments are made to include a period of appointment into Federal service for System members of the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. This period is recognized as part of the uniformed services for purposes of USERRA. Amendments include a period of appointment into Federal service for System members of the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act.
